title: The LFNO Map
name: The LFNO Map
description:
A Map by Lfno

Places referenced in or related to the book Letters From New Orleans, or one of that book's two other online spinoff projects: The &quot;St. James Infirmary&quot;-related Web site &quot;no notes,&quot; and the MLK BLVD Flickr pool.

Letters from New Orleans: 
http://www.robwalker.net/contents/lfno.html

no notes: 
http://lfno.blogspot.com/

MLK BLVD: 
http://www.flickr.com/groups/mlkblvd/

properties.name: Barrister's Gallery
properties.description: Posted by Lfno 1724 Oretha Castle Haley Blvd, New Orleans, LA 70113Location of the Nola Book Fair, among other things.

properties.name: Calliope (or Cooper, on MLK)
properties.description: Posted by LfnoHere\'s a famous housing project, it was home of Master P. The picture was taken in October 2005.

properties.name: Circle Food
properties.description: Posted by Lfno Widely photographed during the low points of the Katrina crisis. These shot were taken in October 2005. Circle Food is mentioned in passing in "Under The Freeway."

properties.name: Club where Alphonce Picou played (Jelly Roll Era)
properties.description: Posted by LfnoIn the 1949 Lomax interviews, Alphonce Picou tells a story about a club on this corner, which he doesn\'t name, where he first heard a blues song in New Orleans... No date specified.

properties.name: Current Base of Operations
properties.description: Posted by LfnoApproximately.

properties.name: Desire
properties.description: Posted by LfnoI\'m sort of guessing about the precise location, but it was somewhere around here. Taken in October 2005.

properties.name: Desire
properties.description: Posted by Lfno3733 Pleasure Street New Orleans, LAThis is where one of the last buildings of the old Desire housing project stood, when I did the interviews for the piece in the book called "The Desire Line."

properties.name: Donna's
properties.description: Posted by Lfno800 N Rampart St, New Orleans, LA 70116Donna\'s, the spot where I heard the Hot 8 version of "St. James Infirmary" that got me started on that whole trip, ini 1998. Also mentioned in the book\'s opening essay, "To New Orleans."

properties.name: Dryades Market (Jelly Roll Era)
properties.description: Posted by LfnoMorton described to Lomax a market Dryades and Melpomene (this section of Melpomone is now MLK), where a man named Robert Charles sold newspapers, in around 1900. In Morton\'s telling, Charles was arrested, and "and the policeman didn’t want him to have his hat." One thing led to another, Charles shot the policeman dead with a Winchester rifle. A riot ensued. "It was known as the New Orleans Riot," Morton said. Various reports or legends indicate that Charles killed a bunch of policemen, and was never caught...

properties.name: Hilma Burt's Mansion / Tom Anderson's Saloon (Jelly Roll era)
properties.description: Posted by LfnoMore spots mentioned by Jelly Roll Morton in his conversations with Alan Lomax. The link leads to a great site that has the best info I can find on these places...

properties.name: Home
properties.description: Posted by LfnoUrsulines & Gayoso, "new orleans"This is the corner where E & I lived, during the LfNO years.

properties.name: Iberville Development
properties.description: Posted by LfnoIn the "Zulu" essay in the book, I mention that that parade is the one that passes a couple of housing projects, including the Iberville projects, which are basically where Storyville used to be...

properties.name: Jelly Roll singing spot
properties.description: Posted by LfnoSpeaking of the turn of the 20th century period, Morton told Lomax in 1938: "They had a very tough bunch . . . of boys. No doubt, there’s some of them still livin’ that frequented one of the corners where I used to sing in the quartets, at Jackson and South Robertson — they called it Jackson and Locust, those days. A very tough gang hung out there — the Pickett Boys. There was Buss, there was Nert, there was Nonny, there was Bob. And they had another one. I don’t remember his name. Well, they lived way back of town, as they called it in New Orleans, out Jackson Street."

properties.name: Joe's Cozy Corner
properties.description: Posted by Lfno1532 Ursulines Ave New Orleans, LA 70116The bar where, on a return visit to NO in late 2003 or thereabouts, I met with GK and the Letters from NO deal got done. There\'s more to say about this place -- later.

properties.name: K-Doe Column
properties.description: Posted by LfnoUnder the freeway, near the Mother In Law.. Taken a month post-Katrina.

properties.name: Lafayette Cemetery No. 1: The Schloegel Findings
properties.description: Posted by LfnoHere\'s the cemetary noted in the essay "The Schloegel Findings," in the book...

properties.name: Liuzza's By The Track
properties.description: Posted by Lfno1518 N Lopez St, New Orleans, LA 70119Where E & I spent New Year\'s eve when we first got to New Orleans, as mentioned in the opening essay, "To New Orleans." Pic is by E, and appears in the book...

properties.name: Louisa & Abundance
properties.description: Posted by LfnoLouisa & October 2005

properties.name: MLK BLVD
properties.description: Posted by LfnoMore from the MLK BLVD project.

properties.name: MLK BLVD
properties.description: Posted by LfnoSome images from the MLK BLVD project (from pre-Katrina).

properties.name: MLK BLVD
properties.description: Posted by LfnoAnother MLK BLVD shot from a few years back.

properties.name: MLK Blvd
properties.description: Posted by LfnoImages from MLK BLVD project

properties.name: Masonic Hall (Jellyroll Era)
properties.description: Posted by LfnoPerdido & Rampart New OrleansJelly Roll Morton names The Masonic Hall, at Perdido and Rampart, as one of the spots Buddy Bolden played, at the turn of the 20th Century.

properties.name: NOLA BOOKFAIR
properties.description: Posted by LfnoSaturday, Oct. 28th, 2006 At Barrister\'s Gallery, 1724 Oretha Castle Haley Blvd, New Orleans, LA

properties.name: Pal's (Yvonne's)
properties.description: Posted by LfnoSite of Pal\'s, which used to be Yvonne\'s, subject of the essay, "Yvonne\'s."

properties.name: Project Food Store
properties.description: Posted by Lfno 2238 Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd. 70113So, this place used to interest me quite a bit. The name, I mean. It was just across from Guste, a public housing project. I believe Guste\'s future is sort of in limbo. When I saw Project Food Store in October 2005, it was clearly done.

properties.name: St. James Methodist Church (Jellyroll Era)
properties.description: Posted by LfnoAccording to Storyvill, New Orleans, by Al Rose, this is the corner where there was at one time a St. James Methodist Church, which some people thought might have had some relation to the song "St. James Infirmary." Actually of course the song (and the reference in it to St. James Hospital) pre-dates Storville, as Rose notes. In any case, this spot is in the middle of the Iberville projects.

properties.name: St. Pauls' Church of God In Christ
properties.description: Posted by Lfno 1020 Forstall St, New Orleans, LA 70117This is the approximate (and possibly the exact) location of the churche that E, our friend Marc, and I visited, described in "The Singing, The Song."

properties.name: The Mother In Law Lounge
properties.description: Posted by Lfno 1500 N Claiborne Ave, New Orleans, LA 70116K-Doe HQ.

properties.name: Tough Babies hangout
properties.description: Posted by Lfnogalvez & jackson, new orleans LouisianaHere\'s a spot where Jelly Roll Morton says certain very rough customers hung out -- the police were said not to go past Claiborne, and these guys, "sweetback men," he suggests, located themselves five blocks back of that, up Jackson, around Galvez.

properties.name: Under The Freeway
properties.description: Posted by LfnoRight around here, by Circle Foods, is the "obituary column" written about in "Under The Freeway."
